properties.field_incident_overview:
EVACUATION ORDER

Evacuation orders are in place for all residents in the OS Properties and Garnet Mountain Property Association (Reforestation area) south of Helmville. Law Enforcement along with Fire Service personnel are assisting and will be making contact door to door. Please leave immediately!

The Montana Red Cross has opened a shelter at the Assembly of God Church in Deer Lodge.

___________________________________________________________________________

This fire is jointly managed between the Bureau of Land Management, the Montana Department of Natural Resources & Conservation (DNRC) and the NW2 Complex Incident Management Team. NW2 Complex IMT, led by Incident Commander John Szulc, assumed command of the Windy Rock Fire at 7 am on August 25. This fire is being managed under a full suppression strategy.

Yesterday: Firefighters focused on pushing heavy equipment and dozer lines around key terrain from Lost Creek, around OS/Garnet Mountain Property Association (Reforestation Area), and tying into the “foot path” area to secure the western edge. Crews responded to multiple spot fires and maintained surge resources in the OS/Garnet Mountain Property Association (Reforestation Area) south of Helmville, MT. Direct line construction continued along Cottonwood Creek, with indirect lines being improved for future operations. In the southeast portion of the fire, crews worked on contingency lines while experiencing mild fire activity. On the southwest portion of the fire, firefighters engaged in scouting efforts to evaluate both direct and contingency line options. Across the fire, aerial mapping and strategic planning supported operational adjustments, while medical and aviation resources were bolstered in preparation for the potential of continued critical fire behavior due to unstable weather conditions and steep terrain.

Today: This morning, Northwest Team 2 (NW2) Complex Incident Management Team assumed command of the Windy Rock Fire from the DNRC County Assist Team. Many personnel are staying on as part of the new organization to ensure continuity in the mission. Public and firefighter safety remain the top priorities as the fire continues to actively spread under challenging weather conditions.

Heavy equipment and dozer operators are reinforcing control lines using existing roads, terrain, and shaded fuel breaks. Crews continue direct handline construction along the fire’s northern edge and structure protection around OS/Garnet Mountain Property Association (Reforestation Area) and Cow Camp. Spot fires and high-intensity fire behavior remain a concern. VLATs (Very Large Air Tankers) and Type 1 helicopters are supporting the ground effort with retardant drops to slow spread toward private property and values at risk.

The fire has crossed onto private land, prompting ongoing structure assessments and protection efforts around the Garnet Mountain subdivision. Hotshot crews continue constructing direct handline on the northern edge of the fire to mitigate spread to private property. Crews will address spot fires in the most active areas, with support from Type 1 helicopters. Very large air tankers (VLATs) will apply retardant to slow the fire’s rate of spread toward critical values at risk..
properties.title: Windy Rock Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Sleeper Ranch fire experienced extreme fire behavior and rapid growth during the Initial Attack. Aircraft continue to work the fire today as additional ground resources work their way to the fire.  

A Type 3 Incident Management Team has been ordered and is enroute.
properties.title: Sleeper Ranch Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Cottonwood Peak Fire is burning in brush and grass 3 miles North or Tuscarora, NV. 

CURRENT SITUATION:

Due to significant increase in moisture (relative humidity and light precipitation) the fire displayed minimal fire behavior on Sunday and Monday. High moisture levels are assisting firefighters in building containment and putting out "hot spots". Night shift will be phasing back to day shift and information will begin being shared once each day (instead of each 12 hour shift).

Thunderstorms and rain are in the forecast for Tuesday.

BE AWARE:

  • The Bureau of Land Management has temporarily closed Wilson Reservoir Campground.
  • The Humboldt-Toiyabe National Forest has temporarily closed the Wild Horse Crossing and Jack Creek campgrounds.
  • The Nevada Department of Transportation has closed Highway 226 between the intersection with Highway 225 to Maggie Summit Road.
properties.title: Cottonwood Peak

properties.field_incident_overview: The Mire Fire is a lightning caused fire burning near Mire Creek on the Nez Perce-Clearwater National Forests' Lochsa-Powell Ranger District.
properties.title: Mire

properties.field_incident_description:
The McAllister Fire is located on private, state, and BLM land 3 miles south or Norris, and 3 miles north of Ennis Lake, on either side of HWY 287. The fire is burning mainly grass and scattered patches of trees.
There is an evacuation warning for residents in the area between Bradley Creek, Shining Mountains West, and US Highway 287.
properties.field_incident_overview:
The McAllister Fire was reported around 5:15pm, Saturday August 16th. The cause of the fire was lightning. 

As of Monday morning, 8/25, the fire is estimated at 3,560 acres with 85% containment. 

Crews are working around the perimeter of the fire in creating 3-chain lengths around the entire perimeter (1-chain length is 66 feet) and combing the interior for heat patches.

Resources will continue operations with the objective to creating a cold, secure buffer around the entire perimeter. Personnel will also work to suppress activity within the small interior heat patches. 

The evacuation warning has been lifted as of 8/20/25 for the areas between Bradley Creek, Shining Mountains West and US Highway 287 (between mile markers 61 and 64). There are no current road closures in place.

Firefighters ask that everyone use caution when traveling through Norris to get to Ennis on HWY 287 as equipment is staged at the top of Norris Hill.
properties.title: McAllister Fire

properties.field_incident_description: Discovered late Tuesday afternoon August 19, by the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) Arizona Strip District while checking a remote lookout camera, the fire is likely a hold over from recent lightning activity.
properties.field_incident_overview:
News Release
BLM Arizona Strip District 

Media Contact: Rachel T. Carnahan, rcarnahan@blm.gov, 435-688-3303

August 22, 2025 

 

Wildfire Fact Sheet – One Way Fire 

Multiple fire resources dispatched to One Way Fire 

 

Start Date: Discovered late Tuesday afternoon August 19, by the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) Arizona Strip District while checking a remote lookout camera, the fire is likely a hold over from recent lightning activity. 

Location: Approximately 38 miles south of St. George, UT, within Arizona

 

Jurisdiction: Grand Canyon-Parashant National Monument, Arizona Strip District, Bureau of Land Management

 

Fire Size: 216 acres [Mapped August 19]

 

Containment: 95%

 

Cause: Lightning

 

Fuels: Grass, shrub, pinyon juniper

 

Structures: No structures threatened. Fire managers are requesting the public’s assistance by traveling cautiously in the area to allow fire resources to access the fire. 

 

Fire Crews/Resources: Firefighting resources from Color Country Interagency Fire including Bureau of Land Management, U.S. Forest Service and National Park Service are assisting on this fire: six engines, two water tenders, one Type 3 helicopter, and a three-person squad. 

 

 

Highlights: Crews will continue securing the perimeter and mop-up operations. For additional information, please contact the Arizona Strip Field Office at 435-688-3200 or check BLM Arizona Facebook or BLM Arizona Fire X/Twitter

 

-BLM-

 

The BLM manages roughly 245 million acres of public land located primarily in 12 western states, including Alaska, on behalf of the American people. The BLM also administers 700 million acres of sub-surface mineral estate throughout the nation. Our mission is to sustain the health, diversity, and productivity of America’s public lands for the use and enjoyment of present and future generations.
properties.title: One Way Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Derby Fire was ignited by lightning on an extremely steep cliff face in a remote area near the Flat Tops Wilderness on Saturday evening. Initial attack efforts by smokejumpers on Sunday were hindered by rollout of burning material, repeatedly igniting the slope below the main fire. 

Protection of life and property are key objectives for managing this fire.

Northern Rockies Complex Incident Management Team 3 assumed command of the fire on the morning of Wednesday, August 20.
properties.title: Derby Fire

properties.field_incident_description: Lightning/Natural
properties.field_incident_overview: In the early afternoon on August 19, fire personnel responded to a smoke report just north of Flesher Pass. Fire personnel responded immediately utilizing both helicopters and airtankers to assist hand crews putting in direct line. Dry fuels, low humidity, and warm weather led to rapid fire growth on the Sandbar 2 fire. The fire continues to grow and remains active in steep, difficult-to-access terrain where there are high levels of dry, dead trees. Today, fire personnel continue to use a full suppression strategy and will be able to go direct assisted by very large airtankers and helicopter water drops. The fire is visible from Montana State Highway 279 and is less than one mile from private structures and land. Please be mindful of increased fire personnel on Flesher Pass Road #279 and slow down to protect our firefighters’ safety. Please avoid stopping on the road or pullouts as this affects firefighter safety and operations. On Friday August 22, at 0700 hrs., command of the fire was transferred to Northwest Complex Incident Management Team 8, with Ed Hyatt serving as Incident Commander.
properties.title: Sandbar 2 Fire

properties.field_incident_description: Wildfire
properties.field_incident_overview:
The West Fork Fire Started on 8/19/2025, located 23 miles northwest of West Yellowstone, Montana, in the South Madison's just North of the Beaver Creek FS cabin, Hebgen Ranger District, Custer Gallatin National Forest.

The fire does not currently pose a threat to Big Sky. Please stay away from aviation working at Hebgen Lake. Aviation aircraft may be dipping out of Hebgen Lake. DO NOT operate drones in the fire area or the Hebgen Lake area, this will cause all firefighting aircraft to be grounded immediately. There is a temporary Flight Restriction in place in the fire area.

No evacuations ordered at this point in time.
properties.title: West Fork Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Corral Creek fire is a wildfire that is approximately 6.5 miles south-southeast of Huson, Montana. The fire, which is burning in timber, was reported on August 20, 2025. 

Firefighting efforts have included the use of helicopters to dump water, and Large Air Tankers dropped retardant to slow the spread. The Lolo National Forest is the lead protecting agency for the incident.

The cause of the fire is a lightning holdover.
properties.title: Corral Creek Fire

properties.field_incident_overview: The Twin Fire is a lightning caused fire burning in the remote backcountry of the North Fork Ranger District on the Nez Perce-Clearwater National Forests. Due to the combination of the steep & rugged terrain, lack of local resources, and higher priority fires on other parts of the Forest, Fire Managers will not be committing suppression resources to this fire. This fire will be monitored closely and the public is being asked to please avoid the fire area while the closure order is being prepared and finalized. Official closure and details should be available by Monday August 25th.
properties.title: Twin

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Dollar Lake Fire is burning in the Green River Lakes area of the Bridger-Teton National Forest's Pinedale Ranger District. The fire was reported at 2:16 p.m. on Thursday, August 21.

Dollar Lake is located along a 25-mile dirt and gravel road that follows the Green River through the national forest. The road is a popular camping and recreation site. In a matter of hours on Aug. 21, the wind-driven fire grew from 20 acres to 600 acres in size. The fast-moving fire prompted the Sublette County Sheriff's office to immediately issue a road closure and evacuation of the area.

The cause of the fire has not been determined.

The fire danger rating for the area remains at very high, and fire restrictions are in effect on the Bridger-Teton National Forest. Learn more by clicking this link to the Stage 1 Fire Restrictions, placed on August 12, 2025 (order #04-03-25-304).
properties.title: Dollar Lake Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Willow Creek Fie was reported on Friday, August 22 on the Greys River District of the Bridger-Teton National Forest, burning in timber southwest of the town of Smoot. Initial resources included an engine and helitack working to suppress the fire, with air attack quickly on scene utilizing three helicopters and two air tankers. This is a full suppression fire.

The fire danger rating for the area remains at very high, and fire restrictions are in effect on the Bridger-Teton National Forest. Learn more by clicking this link to the Stage 1 Fire Restrictions, placed on August 12, 2025 (order #04-03-25-304)

A Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) is in effect for the Willow Creek Fire response area. Click here to read more about the TFR and the important life and safety restrictions on drone use.
properties.title: Willow Creek

properties.field_incident_overview:
At approximately 3:00 p.m. Friday, August 22, 2025, the Little Fire started along the side of SR-178, 5 miles west of Borel Road. Multiple agencies responded including U.S. Forest Service, Kern County Fire Department, Bureau of Land Management, Kern County Sheriff's Office, California Highway Patrol, and Caltrans. The terrain is steep and rocky, with extremely dry vegetation. The fire is under investigation. 

Evacuations: An Evacuation Order is in effect for zone KRN-709B. Evacuation Warnings are in effect for zones KRN-709A, KRN 708, KRN-712, and KRN-713.

Road Closures: SR-178 was closed shortly after units arrived on scene and will remain closed. The Old Kern Canyon Road remains open for travelers. Rancheria Road (25S15) is closed. Kern River access in the area for recreation has also been closed (from Borel Rd to Delonegha Day Use Area).

Area Closures: Keysville Special Recreation Management Area.
properties.title: Little Fire 2025

properties.field_incident_description: Wildfire
properties.field_incident_overview:
The Flat Fire began on the afternoon of August 21st approximately seven miles southwest of Culver, Oregon. Local fire departments, the Lower Bridge Rangeland Fire Protection Association, and the Central Oregon Fire Management Services Type 3 team responded and provided initial attack. Warm and windy conditions, along with low fuel moistures, led to rapid fire spread. 

Oregon Governor Tina Kotek invoked the Conflagration Act on the morning of August 22nd due to threats to life and property. The Oregon Department of Forestry Complex Incident Management Team 3 and Oregon State Fire Marshal Red Team assumed unified command of the incident at 1800 on August 23rd. 

Following several days of active fire behavior and point protection around homes, crews worked overnight on August 24th to fully line spot fires and slop over, and to increase hand and dozer line. 5% containment was reported on August 25th. The Deschutes County Sheriff's Office reported that four primary residences and six other structures were destroyed, and one residence and one other structure were damaged.   bb 

A community meeting is being held at the Sisters High School at 6 pm on August 25th and will also be live streamed on the Sisters-Camp Sherman Fire District Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/share/174J9nNKk2/
properties.title: Flat Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Garnet Fire is 4,400 acres burning in grass and brush in an area with limited access and steep terrain.  This is a full suppression fire.

The Sierra National Forest is fully engaged and effectively working with our cooperative partners toward a goal of protecting values in a safe and efficient manner to provide for emergency personnel and public safety at all times. 

There are 150 personnel assigned with multiple pending requests coming in. Two Type 2 and 1 Type 1 helicopters are assigned.  The fire is at 0 percent containment. 

A Complex Incident Management Team will be coming in this afternoon to transition management of this incident
properties.title: Garnet Fire
